elements.content: By utilizing zinc amalgam as an in situ reductant and pH regulator, mild hydrothermal reaction between UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O, H2SO4, and Cs2CO3 or between UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O, C2H4(SO3H)2, and K2CO3 yielded a novel cesium UIV sulfate trimer Cs4[U3O­(SO4)7]·2.2H2O (1) and a new potassium UIV disulfonic hexamer K­[U6O4(OH)5(H2O)5]­[C2H4(SO3)2]6·6H2O (2), respectively. Compound 1 features a lamellar structure with a honeycomb lattice, and it represents an unprecedented trimeric UIV cluster composed of purely inorganic moieties. Complex 2 is built from hexanuclear U4+ cores and K+ ions interconnected by μ5-[C2H4(SO3)2]2– groups, leading to the construction of an extended framework rather than commonly observed discrete, neutral molecular sulfonate clusters. The various binding modes of the sulfate and disulfonate groups, especially the multidentate ones, enable additional bridging between metal ions, which promotes oligomerization and isolation of polynuclear species. Furthermore, compound 1 exhibits both ion-exchange properties and the Alexandrite effect, and it is the second example of a uranium complex without chromic functional ligands displaying the latter feature.

Compound 1 features a lamellar structure with a honeycomb lattice, and it represents an unprecedented trimeric UIV cluster composed of purely inorganic moieties. Complex 2 is built from hexanuclear U4+ cores and K+ ions interconnected by μ5-[C2H4(SO3)2]2- groups, leading to the construction of an extended framework rather than commonly observed discrete, neutral molecular sulfonate clusters. The various binding modes of the sulfate and disulfonate groups, especially the multidentate ones, enable additional bridging between metal ions, which promotes oligomerization and isolation of polynuclear species. Furthermore, compound 1 exhibits both ion-exchange properties and the Alexandrite effect, and it is the second example of a uranium complex without chromic functional ligands displaying the latter feature.

elements.content: The solid-state chemistry of uranium is remarkably intricate, since uranium can adopt diverse valences and coordination environments. The most common oxidation states of uranium are hexavalent UVI and tetravalent UIV. In the former state, UVI is typically present as the uranyl dication UO2 2+, and it is the most stable form of U under ambient conditions. However, UIV can be encountered in natural minerals, such as coffinite and uraninite. Uranium dioxide, UO2, occurs naturally in uraninite and is used mainly as fuel in nuclear reactors. Contrasting sharply with the bipyramidal structures that UO2 2+ typically adopts, coordination geometries of UIV resemble those of ThIV and tetravalent transuranic metals, for example, NpIV and PuIV, all of which can be 8-, 9-, or 10-coordinate with O atoms. The reduction potential of UO2 2+ to U4+ is only 0.27 V in acidic conditions, making it a feasible reduction. Indeed, UO2 2+ can be easily reduced to UIV under anaerobic environments in the presence of organics, microbes, or iron-containing minerals. Furthermore, various organic species, such as acetate and oxalic acid, can function as reducing agents to prepare UIV materials. For example, large families of UIV-bearing fluorides have been prepared in situ via mild hydrothermal reactions by using uranyl acetate as a reactant without any other reductants.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The solid-state chemistry of uranium is remarkably intricate, since uranium can adopt diverse valences and coordination environments. The most common oxidation states of uranium are hexavalent UVI and tetravalent UIV. In the former state, UVI is typically present as the uranyl dication UO2 2+, and it is the most stable form of U under ambient conditions. However, UIV can be encountered in natural minerals, such as coffinite and uraninite. Uranium dioxide, UO2, occurs naturally in uraninite and is used mainly as fuel in nuclear reactors. Contrasting sharply with the bipyramidal structures that UO2 2+ typically adopts, coordination geometries of UIV resemble those of ThIV and tetravalent transuranic metals, for example, NpIV and PuIV, all of which can be 8-, 9-, or 10-coordinate with O atoms. The reduction potential of UO2 2+ to U4+ is only 0.27 V in acidic conditions, making it a feasible reduction. Indeed, UO2 2+ can be easily reduced to UIV under anaerobic environments in the presence of organics, microbes, or iron-containing minerals. Furthermore, various organic species, such as acetate and oxalic acid, can function as reducing agents to prepare UIV materials. For example, large families of UIV-bearing fluorides have been prepared in situ via mild hydrothermal reactions by using uranyl acetate as a reactant without any other reductants.

elements.content: UIV is susceptible to hydrolysis and condensation in aqueous solution, resulting in the formation of soluble oxo-hydroxo clusters and colloids, as well as uraninite. These uranium moieties play an important role in separation processes used in the nuclear industry, and their significant discrepancies in solubility largely could affect the distribution and fate of reduced uranium in the environment. The number of reported UIV polynuclear clusters has rapidly expanded in the past decades with the formation and isolation of dimers, trimers, tetramers, hexamers, octamers, decamers, dodecamers, hexadecamers, and U38 poly oxo-metalate species. Among these clusters, the largest family of oxo-hydroxo clusters is the hexanuclear species, which shares a similar [M6(OH)4O4]12+ core with the UiO-66/67 metal organic frameworks (MOFs). The [M6(OH)4O4]12+ core can be stabilized by ligands including sulfate, phosphate, triflate, and various carboxylic groups, within which, carboxylic groups are the most represented. Moreover, the use of dicarboxylate linkers enables the formation of MOFs whose pore sizes in the open frameworks can be fine-tuned using ditopic ligands.
elements.clean_text: UIV is susceptible to hydrolysis and condensation in aqueous solution, resulting in the formation of soluble oxo-hydroxo clusters and colloids, as well as uraninite. These uranium moieties play an important role in separation processes used in the nuclear industry, and their significant discrepancies in solubility largely could affect the distribution and fate of reduced uranium in the environment. The number of reported UIV polynuclear clusters has rapidly expanded in the past decades with the formation and isolation of dimers, trimers, tetramers, hexamers, octamers, decamers, dodecamers, hexadecamers, and U38 poly oxo-metalate species. Among these clusters, the largest family of oxo-hydroxo clusters is the hexanuclear species, which shares a similar [M6(OH)4O4]12+ core with the UiO-66/67 metal organic frameworks (MOFs). The [M6(OH)4O4]12+ core can be stabilized by ligands including sulfate, phosphate, triflate, and various carboxylic groups, within which, carboxylic groups are the most represented. Moreover, the use of dicarboxylate linkers enables the formation of MOFs whose pore sizes in the open frameworks can be fine-tuned using ditopic ligands.

elements.content: In comparison to carboxylates, sulfate and sulfonate can exhibit more variable binding modes from monodentate to multidentate due to the additional S–O bonds (four for sulfate and six for disulfonate). The multidentate bridging units have been proven to promote oligomerization and formation of polynuclear species. As a result, sulfate has been extensively studied as a ligand to separate oligomeric actinide species from solution; however, the isolated complexes are limited within hexamers including An­(OH)2SO4 (An = Th and U), and Th3[Th6(OH)4O4(H2O)6]­(SO4)12(H2O)13, as well as monomers. Sulfonates are weaker ligands in terms of coordinating ability, and as a result of such, they have been used less frequently in the design of MOFs due to their less robust nature to sustain permanent pores. Thuéry and co-workers have synthesized a large family of uranyl sulfonate complexes, but UIV sulfonate compounds are relatively scarce, and UIV clusters with sulfonate groups are rarely isolated. UIV sulfonate hexamers are exclusively stabilized by triflate, CF3SO3 –.

As a result, sulfate has been extensively studied as a ligand to separate oligomeric actinide species from solution; however, the isolated complexes are limited within hexamers including An(OH)2SO4 (An = Th and U), and Th3[Th6(OH)4O4(H2O)6](SO4)12(H2O)13, as well as monomers. Sulfonates are weaker ligands in terms of coordinating ability, and as a result of such, they have been used less frequently in the design of MOFs due to their less robust nature to sustain permanent pores. Thuéry and co-workers have synthesized a large family of uranyl sulfonate complexes, but UIV sulfonate compounds are relatively scarce, and UIV clusters with sulfonate groups are rarely isolated. UIV sulfonate hexamers are exclusively stabilized by triflate, CF3SO3 -.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis and structure elucidation of two novel UIV sulfate/sulfonate oligomers, Cs4[U3O­(SO4)7]·2.2H2O (1) and K­[U6O4(OH)5(H2O)5]­[C2H4(SO3)2]6·6H2O (2) by utilizing zinc amalgam as an in situ reductant and pH regulator. Compound 1 represents the first trimeric UIV cluster composed of purely inorganic moieties, and 2 features an extended framework composed of hexanuclear clusters. In addition, complex 1 is one of the rare uranium materials that exhibit both ion-exchange properties and the Alexandrite effect.

Compound 1 represents the first trimeric UIV cluster composed of purely inorganic moieties, and 2 features an extended framework composed of hexanuclear clusters. In addition, complex 1 is one of the rare uranium materials that exhibit both ion-exchange properties and the Alexandrite effect.

Experimental Section

Synthesis

  Caution!   238U is an α-emitting radioisotope and chemically toxic metal. All operations with uranium compounds should be performed in a certified laboratory that is designed for actinide element studies. Standard protections for radioactive materials must be followed.

elements.content: UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O (99.9%, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences), concentrated H2SO4 (98%, Alfa-Aesar), 1,2-ethanedisulfonic acid (99%, Aladdin), Rb2CO3 (99%, Aladdin), K2CO3 (99.99%, Aladdin), Zn (99.99%, Aladdin), and Hg (99.9%, Aladdin) were used as received. Millipore-filtered water with a resistance of 18.2 MΩ·cm was used in all reactions.
elements.clean_text:
Materials

UO2(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (99.9%, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences), concentrated H2SO4 (98%, Alfa-Aesar), 1,2-ethanedisulfonic acid (99%, Aladdin), Rb2CO3 (99%, Aladdin), K2CO3 (99.99%, Aladdin), Zn (99.99%, Aladdin), and Hg (99.9%, Aladdin) were used as received. Millipore-filtered water with a resistance of 18.2 MΩ⋅cm was used in all reactions.

elements.content: UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.0848 g), Cs2CO3 (0.6 mmol, 0.1955 g), and 1 M H2SO4 (2 mmol, 2 mL were loaded into an autoclave with a 23 mL internal volume. Zn amalgam was prepared according to the method by Cross et al., and the amalgam was placed at the bottom of a Teflon liner. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 150 °C for 2 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The product was washed with deionized water to remove soluble solids, followed by rinsing with ethanol. Most crystals of 1 precipitated at the bottom of the liner, while a few crystals stuck on the surface of Zn amalgam and could be isolated easily by scratching with a glass stick. The product consisted of green plates of 1 as a pure phase with 31.8% yield based on U.

elements.content: UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.0848 g), 1,2-ethanedisulfonic acid (2 mmol, 0.3804 g), K2CO3 (0.6 mmol, 0.0827 g), and deionized water (2 mL) were loaded into an autoclave with a 23 mL internal volume, and the Zn amalgam was placed at the bottom of the Teflon liner. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 120 °C for 2 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Same procedures as 1 were followed. Compound 2 could be isolated easily as a pure phase from the Zn amalgam, and the product consisted of green tablets of 2 with 68.5% yield based on U.

K[U6O4(OH)5(H2O)5][C2H4(SO3)2]6⋅6H2O (2)

UO2(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.0848 g), 1,2-ethanedisulfonic acid (2 mmol, 0.3804 g), K2CO3 (0.6 mmol, 0.0827 g), and deionized water (2 mL) were loaded into an autoclave with a 23 mL internal volume, and the Zn amalgam was placed at the bottom of the Teflon liner. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 120 °C for 2 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Same procedures as 1 were followed. Compound 2 could be isolated easily as a pure phase from the Zn amalgam, and the product consisted of green tablets of 2 with 68.5% yield based on U.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker D8-Venture single-crystal X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Turbo X-ray Source (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.710 73 Å) adopting the direct-drive rotating-anode technique and a CMOS detector at 173 K. The data frames were collected using the program APEX2 and processed using the SAINT routine. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-2014 program. All non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. During the refinement of 1, a large residual electron density was located within the channels of 1. The electron density was modeled with Cs(2) with a refined occupancy of ∼33%, thus constrained to 33.3% for further refinement considering the electroneutrality of the structure, which gave rise to reasonable displacement parameters and Cs–O bond distances. Selected crystallographic information is listed in . Atomic coordinates and additional structural information are provided in the CIFs (Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Studies

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker D8-Venture single-crystal X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Turbo X-ray Source (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) adopting the direct-drive rotating-anode technique and a CMOS detector at 173 K. The data frames were collected using the program APEX2 and processed using the SAINT routine. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-2014 program. All non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. During the refinement of 1, a large residual electron density was located within the channels of 1. The electron density was modeled with Cs(2) with a refined occupancy of ~33%, thus constrained to 33.3% for further refinement considering the electroneutrality of the structure, which gave rise to reasonable displacement parameters and Cs-O bond distances. Selected crystallographic information is listed in . Atomic coordinates and additional structural information are provided in the CIFs (Supporting Information).

elements.content: UV–Vis–NIR data were acquired from single crystals using a Craic Technologies micro-spectrophotometer. Crystals of 1 and 2 were placed on quartz slides under Krytox oil, and the data were collected from 200 to 800 nm. The exposure time was auto optimized by the Craic software.

elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1 and 2 was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449F3 instrument in the range of 30–900 °C under a nitrogen flow and at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1.

Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Energy-Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) Analysis

SEM images and EDS data were collected on a Phenom ProX SEM with the energy of the electron beam being 15 kV. Crystals were mounted directly on carbon conductive tape. The spectra acquisition time was 60 s, and the EDS results are provided in Figure S2.

elements.content: By utilizing zinc amalgam as an in situ reductant, hydrothermal reactions between UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O, H2SO4, and Cs2CO3 or between UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O, C2H4(SO3H)2, and K2CO3 result in the crystallization of complexes 1 and 2, respectively. Zn amalgam plays two important roles in the synthesis of 1 and 2, as a reductant and pH regulator. Zn in the amalgam has a reduction potential of 0.762 V, which is sufficient to reduce uranyl dications to tetravalent or even to trivalent species. For example, Zn amalgam has been utilized to successfully prepare trivalent uranium sulfates AU­(SO4)2(H2O) (A = Na, Rb, Cs), as well as a mixed-valent uranium (III/IV) sulfate K5U2(SO4)6(H2O). Furthermore, Zn metal in the amalgam can also neutralize the H+ donated from H2SO4 or C2H4(SO3H)2, resulting in a change of pH of the reaction system.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

By utilizing zinc amalgam as an in situ reductant, hydrothermal reactions between UO2(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O, H2SO4, and Cs2CO3 or between UO2(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O, C2H4(SO3H)2, and K2CO3 result in the crystallization of complexes 1 and 2, respectively. Zn amalgam plays two important roles in the synthesis of 1 and 2, as a reductant and pH regulator. Zn in the amalgam has a reduction potential of 0.762 V, which is sufficient to reduce uranyl dications to tetravalent or even to trivalent species. For example, Zn amalgam has been utilized to successfully prepare trivalent uranium sulfates AU(SO4)2(H2O) (A = Na, Rb, Cs), as well as a mixed-valent uranium (III/IV) sulfate K5U2(SO4)6(H2O). Furthermore, Zn metal in the amalgam can also neutralize the H+ donated from H2SO4 or C2H4(SO3H)2, resulting in a change of pH of the reaction system.

elements.content: The pH of the reaction plays a critical role in determining the species of reduction products and in directing oligomer formation. For instance, it is necessary to adjust the pH to 0 to facilitate the formation of cesium UIII sulfate CsU­(SO4)2(H2O), while increasing the pH to 1.13 (measured after the reaction) resulted in the formation of UIV species 1. Further elevating the pH to 4.23 or more basic conditions could enable the precipitation of UO2. In terms of structure, high pH promotes olation/oxolation hydrolysis reactions, which assists the formation of uranium or other actinide oligomers. Comparable reaction with the absence of Zn amalgam for 2 gave rise to the formation of a mononuclear uranyl species UO2[C2H4(SO3)2]­(H2O)3, which has been reported by Thuéry et al. By introducing Zn amalgam, the pH increased from 0.63 to 2.30 when the reaction finished, and a hexanuclear complex 2 was isolated.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 possesses a lamellar structure with open channels and crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group P3̅ (No. 147; a,b). The distance between each layer is ∼3.6 Å. The honeycomb lattice of 1 is reminiscent of the uranium open framework U3O­(btc)3(OH)­(H2O)2·2.5DMF·1.5H2O (btc = bis­(trichlormethyl)­carbonate; DMF = dimethylformamide), which employs in its syntheses an organic trimesate ligand as a templating agent. Complex 1 represents a less-common example of an open-channel structure, since it combines the binding complexities associated with purely inorganic moieties UIV and SO4 2–. The one-dimensional (1D) hexagonal tubular channels of 1 extend along the c-axis and have a dimension of 8.378(9) × 8.378(9) Å. Cs(2)+ ions reside in the channels in a hexagonal manner created by the 3̅ symmetry, while Cs(1)+ ions and disordered hydrating water molecules locate between the layers.
elements.clean_text:
Structures and Topological Descriptions

Cs4[U3O(SO4)7]⋅2.2H2O (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 possesses a lamellar structure with open channels and crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group P3̅ (No. 147; a,b). The distance between each layer is ~3.6 Å. The honeycomb lattice of 1 is reminiscent of the uranium open framework U3O(btc)3(OH)(H2O)2⋅2.5DMF⋅1.5H2O (btc = bis(trichlormethyl)carbonate; DMF = dimethylformamide), which employs in its syntheses an organic trimesate ligand as a templating agent. Complex 1 represents a less-common example of an open-channel structure, since it combines the binding complexities associated with purely inorganic moieties UIV and SO4 2-. The one-dimensional (1D) hexagonal tubular channels of 1 extend along the c-axis and have a dimension of 8.378(9) × 8.378(9) Å. Cs(2)+ ions reside in the channels in a hexagonal manner created by the 3̅ symmetry, while Cs(1)+ ions and disordered hydrating water molecules locate between the layers.

elements.content: The anionic [U3O­(SO4)7]4– layer is composed of [UIV 3(μ3-O)]10+ trinuclear cores decorated by three crystallographically independent SO4 2– anions as shown in c. Trinuclear oligomer is a relatively rare motif with actinides, and fewer than 10 tetravalent actinide trimers have been reported. Compound 1 is the only trimeric UIV cluster composed of purely inorganic moieties. The μ3-O­(11) atom resides on the 3̅ axis in the [001] direction, and it coordinates with three UIV ions generated from the symmetry operation, forming a trimeric polynuclear species (a). Three sulfate anions exhibit completely different binding modes with UIV ions. Specifically, S(1)­O4 2– functions as a μ3-bridging unit, and it coordinates with three UIV ions of a single trimer through S–O(3) × 3 bonds (b). Both S(2)­O4 2– and S(3)­O4 2– connect two distinct trinuclear cores to each other, but S(2)­O4 2– chelates with UIV ions in edge- or corner-sharing modes, while S(3)­O4 2– exclusively coordinates with UIV ions in a corner-sharing manner. Each [UIV 3(μ3-O)]10+ core is coordinated by 13 sulfate groups (S(1)­O4 2– × 1, S(2)­O4 2– × 6, and S(3)­O4 2– × 6). The UIV center of the hexamer is coordinated by nine O atoms, of which one is μ3-O, and the rest are donated from sulfate groups. The geometry of UIV can be best defined as a monocapped square antiprism (c). Selected interatomic distances for U–U, U–O, and S–O are listed in , all of which agree well with the literature.

The trinuclear core in 1 is interestingly similar to the trimeric center reported by Loiseau et al., as illustrated in Figure S3a,b, respectively. Both cores feature a trigonal geometry that consists of 3 U and 22 O atoms; however, their structures are different in the following aspects. First, the trinuclear core in 1 is built from three UIV atoms bridged by a μ3-O and a μ3-SO4 2–, while only μ3-O participates in the μ3-bridging of the trimeric cores in U3O­(btc)3(OH)­(H2O)2·2.5DMF·1.5H2O. Second, O atoms coordinating with UIV are exclusively donated from sulfates for 1; however, oxo-, hydroxo-, and water molecules are involved in coordinating with UIV for the latter compound. Third, the coordination numbers of UIV for these two compounds are different, which are nine for 1 and eight for U3O­(btc)3(OH)­(H2O)2·2.5DMF·1.5H2O.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group R3̅ (No. 148) and adopts a dense three-dimensional (3D) topology as shown in a,b. The framework is built from hexanuclear UIV cores that are interconnected by μ5-[C2H4(SO3)2]2– with K+ ions, as shown in c. This deviates from the hexamers isolated by μ2-triflate ligands, which terminate and yield discrete 0 D clusters. The hexanuclear core is composed of one crystallographically independent UIV metal center bridged by two unique μ3-OH or μ3-O ligands, forming a superoctahedral motif (a). Similar motifs have been observed for a wide variety of tetravalent metals, including Th, U, Np, Pu, Zr, and Ce.

This deviates from the hexamers isolated by μ2-triflate ligands, which terminate and yield discrete 0 D clusters. elements.content: Distinguishing the μ3-OH or μ3-O ligands from the M–O bonds has proven to be rather challenging (using XRD), since hydrogen atoms are difficult to explicitly locate during structural refinement. Furthermore, the high symmetry of the rhombohedral framework in this particular case elevates the difficulty, because a unique 2O(1)–6O(2) combination for the hexanuclear core (a) was generated by the symmetric operation through the 3̅ axis, which contrasts sharply with the most commonly observed [M6(μ3-OH)4(μ3-O4)]12+ cores in lower symmetry. Inspecting the MIV–O bond distance is a possible solution to differentiating between μ3-OH and μ3-O from U–O bonds. In 2, the average bond distances of U–O(1) and U–O(2) are 2.295(2) and 2.33(4) Å, respectively, which correspond to values between U–OH (2.40–2.50 Å) and U–O (2.20–2.27 Å) bonds calculated from the published UIV hexanuclear motif in lower symmetry. This result suggests that the O or OH species could be delocalized on the μ3 nodes. Indeed, residual electron density can be located near both O(1) and O(2) with distances of 0.6–0.7 Å (Figure S4). Similar delocalization has been observed in a highly symmetrical uranium sulfate U6O4(OH)4(SO4)6 (I 4/m) and UIV dicarboxylate [U6O4(OH)4(H2O)6(L)6]·X (L = dicarboxylate ligand; X = DMF) (Fm3̅m) complexes. Considering the electroneutrality of the structure, the hexanuclear core in 2 is defined as the most commonly observed [U6(μ3-OH)4(μ3-O)4]12+ with protons in a tetrahedral arrangement on the hexagonal faces, which has proven to be the most energetically favorable site for protons. Bond valence calculations (BVS) resulted in values of 4.063 for U, suggesting the existence of UIV in 2.

elements.content: The UIV center of the hexamer is coordinated by nine O atoms, the geometry of which can be best defined as a monocapped square antiprism (b). Of the nine O atoms, four of these are μ3-O­(H), four are donated from sulfonate groups, and the last was assigned to a coordinating water molecule. The bond distances of U–Ow and U–Osulfonate are 2.719 (4) and 2.427(4)–2.529(4) Å, respectively, which agree well with literature. The interatomic distances for U–U are listed in . The [U6(μ3-OH)4(μ3-O4)]12+ cores are linked to each other through 12 [C2H4(SO3)2]2– ligands (c), and each of them functions as μ5-bridging ligands with four UIV centers and one K+ ion. Because of the presence of one crystallographically unique K+ in 2, a negative charge is required to ensure the electroneutrality of the framework. Consequently, the partial occupancy of OH–/H2O can be considered for the coordinating water Ow1 or for the unbound Ow2 site (with an OH/H2O ratio of 1/5). Considering 2 was isolated from acidic conditions, partial OH–/H2O occupancy of the terminal U–Ow1 is more plausible due to the propensity of UIV to undergo hydrolysis. Similar statistical distribution of OH–/H2O was previously reported in U3O­(btc)3(OH)­(H2O)2·2.5DMF·1.5H2O.

The bond distances of U-Ow and U-Osulfonate are 2.719 (4) and 2.427(4)-2.529(4) Å, respectively, which agree well with literature. The interatomic distances for U-U are listed in . The [U6(μ3-OH)4(μ3-O4)]12+ cores are linked to each other through 12 [C2H4(SO3)2]2- ligands (c), and each of them functions as μ5-bridging ligands with four UIV centers and one K+ ion. Because of the presence of one crystallographically unique K+ in 2, a negative charge is required to ensure the electroneutrality of the framework. Consequently, the partial occupancy of OH-/H2O can be considered for the coordinating water Ow1 or for the unbound Ow2 site (with an OH/H2O ratio of 1/5). Considering 2 was isolated from acidic conditions, partial OH-/H2O occupancy of the terminal U-Ow1 is more plausible due to the propensity of UIV to undergo hydrolysis. Similar statistical distribution of OH-/H2O was previously reported in U3O(btc)3(OH)(H2O)2⋅2.5DMF⋅1.5H2O.

elements.content: The exchange capacity of ions in 3D open-frameworks and two-dimensional (2D) layered structures has been studied in a variety of actinide oxo-anion materials, including thorium borate, uranyl phosphate, uranyl vanadates, uranyl iodates, etc. The anionic nature of compound 1 suggests the possible cation-exchange behavior. Ion-exchange experiments were conducted by soaking 0.05 g of crystals of 1 in 2 mL of 0.1 M NaCl, KCl, RbCl, CaCl2, MnCl2, and CuCl2 solutions for 1 d. As shown in a, SEM-EDS demonstrated the presence of Na+, K+, or Rb+ in the NaCl, KCl, and RbCl-sorbed crytals, respectively. Partial replacement of Cs+ with Na+ was observed, while Cs+ was almost completely exchanged by K+ and Rb+. The size difference between Cs+ and Rb+/K+ is smaller than that between Cs+ and Na+, revealing that 1 could be more accommodating for Cs+/K+ than it is for Na+. No significant phase transitions were observed before and after ion-exchange as confirmed by their PXRD patterns (b). The Ca2+ ion appeared to be exchangable with Cs+ at a first glance, but both exfoliation of the crystals and a phase transition were observed, as shown in Figure S5, indicating the Ca2+ uptake is likely due to recrystallization rather than ion exchange. For MnCl2 and CuCl2, no obvious ion exchange occurred after immersion of the crystals in their solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Ion-Exchange Studies

The exchange capacity of ions in 3D open-frameworks and two-dimensional (2D) layered structures has been studied in a variety of actinide oxo-anion materials, including thorium borate, uranyl phosphate, uranyl vanadates, uranyl iodates, etc. The anionic nature of compound 1 suggests the possible cation-exchange behavior. Ion-exchange experiments were conducted by soaking 0.05 g of crystals of 1 in 2 mL of 0.1 M NaCl, KCl, RbCl, CaCl2, MnCl2, and CuCl2 solutions for 1 d. As shown in a, SEM-EDS demonstrated the presence of Na+, K+, or Rb+ in the NaCl, KCl, and RbCl-sorbed crytals, respectively. Partial replacement of Cs+ with Na+ was observed, while Cs+ was almost completely exchanged by K+ and Rb+. The size difference between Cs+ and Rb+/K+ is smaller than that between Cs+ and Na+, revealing that 1 could be more accommodating for Cs+/K+ than it is for Na+. No significant phase transitions were observed before and after ion-exchange as confirmed by their PXRD patterns (b). The Ca2+ ion appeared to be exchangable with Cs+ at a first glance, but both exfoliation of the crystals and a phase transition were observed, as shown in Figure S5, indicating the Ca2+ uptake is likely due to recrystallization rather than ion exchange. For MnCl2 and CuCl2, no obvious ion exchange occurred after immersion of the crystals in their solutions.

elements.content: Compound 1 exhibits a brownish color under standard fluorescent lighting, while it appears green under LED or natural lighting (), due to a phenomenon referred to as the Alexandrite effect. This effect has been observed in Cr3+-doped chrysoberyl, lanthanide (Nd and Ho) containing materials, and even transuranic (Np and Am) compounds, but barely reported for uranium-bearing materials. Shi et al. have reported two viologen-based uranyl polymers featuring such an effect; however, their photochromic behaviors originate from the viologen ligands rather than the U ions. To the best of our knowledge, UF3 is the only other reported uranium compound without chromic functional groups that features the Alexandrite effect.
elements.clean_text:
Alexandrite Effect and UV-Vis-NIR Spectroscopy

Compound 1 exhibits a brownish color under standard fluorescent lighting, while it appears green under LED or natural lighting (), due to a phenomenon referred to as the Alexandrite effect. This effect has been observed in Cr3+-doped chrysoberyl, lanthanide (Nd and Ho) containing materials, and even transuranic (Np and Am) compounds, but barely reported for uranium-bearing materials. Shi et al. have reported two viologen-based uranyl polymers featuring such an effect; however, their photochromic behaviors originate from the viologen ligands rather than the U ions. To the best of our knowledge, UF3 is the only other reported uranium compound without chromic functional groups that features the Alexandrite effect.

elements.content: (a) Photographs of 1 showing the Alexandrite effect (a) under standard fluorescent light and (b) under LED light.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Photographs of 1 showing the Alexandrite effect (a) under standard fluorescent light and (b) under LED light.

elements.content: The solid-state UV–vis–NIR absorption spectra were obtained from single crystals of 1 and 2 using a microspectrophotometer and are shown in . Both compounds exhibit absorption ranging from 300 to 400 nm, which can be ascribed to the charge-transfer from U4+ to SO4 2– or [C2H4(SO3)2]2–. Besides the green color of crystal, the tetravalent nature of UIV in 1 and 2 can be confirmed by its signature peaks observed from 400 to 700 nm. UIV has an electron configuration of 5f2, and its characteristic f–f transitions include 3P2 (∼425 nm), 1I6 (∼490 nm), 3P1 (∼545 nm), and a combination of 1G4, 3P0, and 1D2 (580–680 nm) in the ground state, which have been assigned by Carnall et al. The f–f transitions for 1 are much sharper than those for 2, and the existence of such distinct bands in the visible region results in a change of absorption and consequently the Alexandrite effect, even under slightly different lighting conditions.

UIV has an electron configuration of 5f2, and its characteristic f-f transitions include 3P2 (~425 nm), 1I6 (~490 nm), 3P1 (~545 nm), and a combination of 1G4, 3P0, and 1D2 (580-680 nm) in the ground state, which have been assigned by Carnall et al. The f-f transitions for 1 are much sharper than those for 2, and the existence of such distinct bands in the visible region results in a change of absorption and consequently the Alexandrite effect, even under slightly different lighting conditions.

elements.content: The stretching bands of O–H at ∼3600 cm–1 and the H–O–H bending mode at ∼1600 cm–1 confirm the presence of hydrating or coordinating water in 1 and 2 (). The IR spectrum of 1 is dominated by strong bands at 1000–1200 and 600–700 cm–1, which can be attributed to the stretching and bending vibrations, respectively, of the sulfate ligands. Similar vibrational bands have been observed in other Th-sulfate compounds. For compound 2, the stretching and bending vibrations of −CH2– in [C2H4(SO3)2]2– can be observed at 2900–3030 and 1415 cm–1, respectively. Because of the presence of sulfonate groups, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of SO3 – are located at 1244 and 1232 and 1038 cm–1, respectively. The bending vibrations of SO3 – can be found at ∼520 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectroscopy

The stretching bands of O-H at ~3600 cm-1 and the H-O-H bending mode at ~1600 cm-1 confirm the presence of hydrating or coordinating water in 1 and 2 (). The IR spectrum of 1 is dominated by strong bands at 1000-1200 and 600-700 cm-1, which can be attributed to the stretching and bending vibrations, respectively, of the sulfate ligands. Similar vibrational bands have been observed in other Th-sulfate compounds. For compound 2, the stretching and bending vibrations of -CH2- in [C2H4(SO3)2]2- can be observed at 2900-3030 and 1415 cm-1, respectively. Because of the presence of sulfonate groups, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of SO3 - are located at 1244 and 1232 and 1038 cm-1, respectively. The bending vibrations of SO3 - can be found at ~520 cm-1.

elements.content: As shown in Figure S6, 1 underwent two stages of weight loss with a total value of 15.8% up to 540 °C, which corresponds to the removal of two CsOH (calcd 15.5%). The loss of additional Cs atom and other species occurred up to 900 °C. The TGA curve of 2 displays two main stages of weight loss. The first stage ranges from 30 to 200 °C, and it could be attributed to the removal of coordinating water (measured 7.2%, calcd 7.1%). Then a large loss was observed from 370 to 400 °C, corresponding to decomposing [C2H4(SO3)2]2– groups. The remaining weight has a good agreement with the expected value for U3O8 (measured 51.7%, calcd 50.0%).

Thermogravimetric Analysis

As shown in Figure S6, 1 underwent two stages of weight loss with a total value of 15.8% up to 540 °C, which corresponds to the removal of two CsOH (calcd 15.5%). The loss of additional Cs atom and other species occurred up to 900 °C. The TGA curve of 2 displays two main stages of weight loss. The first stage ranges from 30 to 200 °C, and it could be attributed to the removal of coordinating water (measured 7.2%, calcd 7.1%). Then a large loss was observed from 370 to 400 °C, corresponding to decomposing [C2H4(SO3)2]2- groups. The remaining weight has a good agreement with the expected value for U3O8 (measured 51.7%, calcd 50.0%).

elements.content: In summary, we used Zn amalgam as an in situ reductant and pH regulator to isolate UIV polynuclear oligomers from UVI solution. An unprecedented inorganic trimeric UIV cluster 1 with a microporous lamellar lattice was obtained, without the use of any organic ligand or templating agent. Because of the anionic nature of 1 and the presence of dissociated Cs+ in the channels or layers, Cs+ can be exchanged by Na+, K+, and Rb+. In addition, compound 1 exhibits the Alexandrite effect, which is extremely rare for uranium-bearing materials. Meanwhile, a UIV disulfonate hexamer 2 built from [U6(μ3-OH)4(μ3-O4)]12+ cores and μ5-[C2H4(SO3)2]2– groups was isolated by a similar reaction with Zn amalgam. This has been proven to be an excellent in situ reductant that enables isolable UIV oxo-hydroxo clusters without the need to prepare UIV precursors. In addition to functioning as a reductant, Zn amalgam also influenced the pH, which could affect both the constituents and nuclearity of oligomers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we used Zn amalgam as an in situ reductant and pH regulator to isolate UIV polynuclear oligomers from UVI solution. An unprecedented inorganic trimeric UIV cluster 1 with a microporous lamellar lattice was obtained, without the use of any organic ligand or templating agent. Because of the anionic nature of 1 and the presence of dissociated Cs+ in the channels or layers, Cs+ can be exchanged by Na+, K+, and Rb+. In addition, compound 1 exhibits the Alexandrite effect, which is extremely rare for uranium-bearing materials. Meanwhile, a UIV disulfonate hexamer 2 built from [U6(μ3-OH)4(μ3-O4)]12+ cores and μ5-[C2H4(SO3)2]2- groups was isolated by a similar reaction with Zn amalgam. This has been proven to be an excellent in situ reductant that enables isolable UIV oxo-hydroxo clusters without the need to prepare UIV precursors. In addition to functioning as a reductant, Zn amalgam also influenced the pH, which could affect both the constituents and nuclearity of oligomers.

elements.content: The various binding modes that sulfate can adopt enable a rich effect on the speciation and structure of these materials and have proven to be excellent ligands to isolate polynuclear species. Furthermore, we also noted that the combination of large actinide ions with multidentate sulfate often yields materials with open framework, such as compound 1, Th3[Th6(OH)4O4(H2O)6]­(SO4)12(H2O)13, Th3(SO4)6­(H2O)6·H2O, (H3O)8[(H3O)@([18]­crown-6)]2­[(UO2)14(SO4)19(H2O)4]­(H2O)20.5, etc. Although sulfonate groups are notorious for being weak ligands and are therefore used less when synthesizing MOFs, employing these with softer tetravalent actinide cations (Th4+–U4+) allows us to utilize the inherent coordinative flexibility of the ditopic sulfonate group to produce open frameworks. These, and other related studies, are underway.
elements.clean_text: The various binding modes that sulfate can adopt enable a rich effect on the speciation and structure of these materials and have proven to be excellent ligands to isolate polynuclear species. Furthermore, we also noted that the combination of large actinide ions with multidentate sulfate often yields materials with open framework, such as compound 1, Th3[Th6(OH)4O4(H2O)6](SO4)12(H2O)13, Th3(SO4)6(H2O)6⋅H2O, (H3O)8[(H3O)@([18]crown-6)]2[(UO2)14(SO4)19(H2O)4](H2O)20.5, etc. Although sulfonate groups are notorious for being weak ligands and are therefore used less when synthesizing MOFs, employing these with softer tetravalent actinide cations (Th4+-U4+) allows us to utilize the inherent coordinative flexibility of the ditopic sulfonate group to produce open frameworks. These, and other related studies, are underway.

UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.0848 g), Cs2CO3 (0.6 mmol, 0.1955 g), and 1 M H2SO4 (2 mmol, 2 mL were loaded into an autoclave with a 23 mL internal volume. Zn amalgam was prepared according to the method by Cross et al., and the amalgam was placed at the bottom of a Teflon liner. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 150 °C for 2 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. The product was washed with deionized water to remove soluble solids, followed by rinsing with ethanol. Most crystals of 1 precipitated at the bottom of the liner, while a few crystals stuck on the surface of Zn amalgam and could be isolated easily by scratching with a glass stick. The product consisted of green plates of 1 as a pure phase with 31.8% yield based on U.

K­[U<sub>6</sub>O<sub>4</sub>(OH)<sub>5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>5</sub>]­[C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub>(SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>6</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

UO2(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.0848 g), 1,2-ethanedisulfonic acid (2 mmol, 0.3804 g), K2CO3 (0.6 mmol, 0.0827 g), and deionized water (2 mL) were loaded into an autoclave with a 23 mL internal volume, and the Zn amalgam was placed at the bottom of the Teflon liner. The autoclave was sealed and heated to 120 °C for 2 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Same procedures as 1 were followed. Compound 2 could be isolated easily as a pure phase from the Zn amalgam, and the product consisted of green tablets of 2 with 68.5% yield based on U.
